headline: Grandma Jeanette's Amazing German Red Cabbage
description: This German red cabbage recipe with apples simmers to tender perfection giving you time to prepare the main course. Pair it with pork or sausage.

video.name: How to Make Amazing German Red Cabbage

name: Grandma Jeanette's Amazing German Red Cabbage

recipeInstructions.text: Place cabbage, apples, sugar, and butter into a large pot. Pour in vinegar and water, then add salt, pepper, and cloves. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer until the cabbage is tender, 1 1/2 to 2 hours.

review.reviewBody: Excellent! Only change I made was adding additional vinegar. A keeper. Thank you.
I've tried this is less sugar and I think it's best as written. Wonderful flavor and texture. I served it with pork schnitzel and spetzales, Fantastic!

This is the best red cabbage I have eaten. The recipe is perfect just as it is. However, i mistakenly added a fourth of a cup of white vinegar to it too and it was also delicious. I had both vinegars in my recipe.

My German M-I-L used canned red cabbage, the kind in a jar, removed some of the juice, added chopped apple, onion and bacon, some sugar and maybe more vinegar, then covered with water in the pot. After an hour or so, taste and adjust the seasonings if needed. The final thing that makes it authentic is to add some cornstarch to make it a little creamy and thicken the juice a little -- not too much. She was from Weisbaden and this is the way she learned to make it over a hundred years ago.
Instead of ground clove add the following. Truly Bavarian. 1 bay leaf 3 whole cloves 3 juniper berries

Surprisingly wonderful!! Has a nice tangy taste. I have to watch sodium intake so, reduced salt to 1/2 teaspoon. That’s the only change. It’s extremely palatable and it’s now going to be used frequently as I think it will pair with many dishes or great alone. TRY IT❣️❣️❣️❣️❣️

I've had red cabbage all over Bavaria and in many US German restaurants. This is one of the best red cabbage dishes that I've ever had, if not the best. I can't stop eating it. Thank you Grandma Jeanette. Your legacy lives on!
Amazing!! The perfect balance of sweet and sour. This goes so well with many dishes. This recipe is a keeper! I paired with homemade schnitzel and egg noodles ❤️
beautiful and fresh! loved it!
Substituted 6 grams of Svetia for 1/4 cup sugar. Will cut back to 5 grams next time.

I made this tonight and it was just lovely. We like ours a little more sweet and sour so I added more vinegar. Another addition we like is adding about a cup of crumbled bacon and if we have it use bacon fat instead of butter. Brown sugar also gives it a nice caramel flavor.

Easy, just like Oma’s! She always added golden raisins, so I added 1/2 cup to the
recipe!

It was really good but sort of weird: one bite might be a bit salty, the next a little spicy (might have been a little heavy handed with the pepper) and then there would be a bite where everything was just right and it was delicious! So I think next time a little less salt and pepper, because there will be a next time, and then every bite will be perfect.
This is the best red cabbage I have ever tasted! It is better than any German restaurant I have been to. Also, it is so easy.
Delicious. Only change was to omit the sugar entirely to make a healthier dish. Still, that didn’t stop me from consuming the entire pot in one sitting. I could not stop eating it!
Pretty good. I read other recipes and subbed vinegar for a cup of red wine and added nutmeg. Oh and onion.

I love this recipe, I have to say I was hesitant in using cloves, because my husband's mother always made this and used bay leaves then removed them when done. 
Thank you for sharing this delicious recipe — it was a winner for sure.

I made this into a Keto dish! Of course I didn't put in the apples (sad face), but it was just fine anyway. I grew up on this dish. My mother always sautéed onions with the cabbage so I did too. I don't really care for cloves, so I used allspice. Also I used an artificial white sugar and brown sugar to stay Keto. My mother always added caraway seeds so I added about 2 Tb to the dish. Lastly, garnished with some crumbled bacon and a dollop of sour cream on top to serve. This was so good even though I had to make some changes! I didn't have my mother's recipe, so this one worked out perfect! Thank you!

This was delicious and super easy to make! I did use a little less than 1/4 cup sugar based on other reviews. Also, I used whole cloves because that's what I found at the store.
My husband loves German food but doesn't usually eat red cabbage dishes - he really liked this one.

Been using this recipe for years -- it's my go-to side for weisswurst (bockwurst), pork shank and schnitzel. Our friends can't get enough of it, and it's always the only dish gone at my Oktoberfest party. Sehr gut!!
Very good as is but I added a tiny bit more sugar after tasting and about a half tablespoon of caraway seed.
The cloves bring this dish together. Delicious accompaniment to a proper Octoberfest meal.
Way too much salt for our taste.
We used your recipe as inspiration to create our own Blaukraut recipe. It was our first attempt. It turned out amazing!! Thank you for sharing your recipe.
I did not have cloves and substituted some cinnamon. Also used brown sugar instead of white.
This is a wonderful recipe! My family loved it. Sweet, tangy, delicious!

First time trying this, other than at a German restaurant. It was absolutely delicious. I did, however, only have a green cabbage, so used that, and only a Gala apple, so used that as well. I think even the way I made this, it was good, but definitely want to try it the right way next time. Just one more change, followed other reviews and cut down the sugar by 1 TBSP. Glad I did, as I think it would have been too sweet using the whole 1/4 cup. Try this, you’ll love it!

WAY too much sugar! I cut back a bit of what the recipe said and it still was too much. I even added a tad more vinegar but just too sweet. I feel the recipe is worth trying again, but very little sugar next time. Taste and add will be the order of the day.
The only thing I would change next time is to check the consistency at one hour. I may have had my heat turned up a little too high, but by 90 minutes my cabbage was a little TOO cooked.
This was SO delicious!!! Comparable to the red cabbage served at our favorite German restaurants. Made exactly as written - resist the urge to leave out the cloves!
This was very delicious and super simple to prepare

This was amazing. I don’t think Sebastian, a local German restaurant could have made it better. Followed the easy direction with exception of using the slow cooker. I mixed ingredients in a large bowl and transferred to a 4 quart cooker, set on high for 3 hours then low for 3 hours stirring occasionally 
It was “wunderbar”

Made almost exactly as written and it was really good! I made a double batch for the family, but I did not put all the salt in, I put half, as I have one person with high BP....didn't seem to make a difference it was still excellent. Not too sour or too sweet.
I used green cabbage, added 4 med. beets to get the sane red coloring. Otherwise all is the same. Very good will make it again
It's a great red cabbage recipe. I use it whenever I make sauerbraten. I particularly like what the long simmer does to the texture and flavor.
Very good I didn’t have apples so I used apple sauce.Came out great!
My husband loves red cabbage so I decided to try this. It was GREAT! I did not have an apple so I used 1/2 cup of applesauce and it was perfect!

Holy cow, this cabbage is so delicious. I followed the recipe exactly, cooking just over two hours. Served with “Sauerbraten IV” and homemade spaetzle - killed it! Wish I had doubled the cabbage recipe because I just want to eat it by the bowlful!
I really liked this recipe, and it was super easy to make. My family found the cloves a little off-putting. I would make this again, but use less clove or even eliminate it.
I absolutely love this! Maybe my German heritage? My husband loves it as well. I didn’t have cloves but decided to toss in some caraway seeds and boy howdy. Made it pop!

Have followed this recipe and make it a few times. It's absolutely delicious. Have substituted minor changes just because of what I had on hand. Macintosh apples for the Granny Smith, Demerara sugar for the white refined. Today I'm going to use green cabbage because I can't find red. I've also cooked it in the Crock-Pot when I don't feel like being around to watch over it.

I lived in southern Germany for a few years in my 20s and absolutely loved red cabbage. This recipe helps with those bouts of homesickness for the place and foods I love so much! I didn’t change anything in the recipe—I’ve made it 3 or 4 times now.
It was amazing! I am making it again, it was good.
Love it. I used just 1/2 teaspoon of salt and no cloves. I have made it several times.
Used a slow cooker instead. Needs to simmer for 4-5 hrs.

This is great! The only change I made was I doubled it, but cut back on the salt. I put all these ingredients in my crockpot and put it on high for about 6 hours. Made cooking a German meal a lot easier to have one item done before cooking the rest!
What can I say during the pandemic? Things I've loved to eat but never made come to mind and this was one of those things. I really loved it!
We're all on low salt diets, so I cut the salt way down, but for a first try left everything else alone. It's simmering now, can't wait to taste!
Yummy, a family favorite. Have used this recipe many times,no changes needed. I always double recipe because it does cook down. You’ll want seconds

I made this in the crockpot---took only a few hours on high. I used a red apple since I didn't have green and was very conservative with the salt, sugar and vinegar. Adjusted it at the end. This would be crazy good with bacon.
Wonderful side dish to pork tenderloin.
Cook only 1 hour.
Who knew red cabbage could taste so good. The ground cloves gives this dish a warm savory feel. Absolutely delicious!
So Good!!!

This was absolutely delicious! I doubled the recipe for a whole head of red cabbage. Just summed it a full 2.5 hours. Had to add a dab more water at first but removed it via condensation on the lid when stirring every 30-45 minutes. I think I may cut out some of the sugar next time; but, I always like to try recipes as written first before tinkering.

We loved this. Made exactly as written and it was perfect for us. This will be a staple in our home. I also love the idea of using it as a condiment. Trying the leftovers on ham and swiss sandwiches today. Thanks for a great recipe that we all enjoyed and will continue to do so.
It was amazingly delicious. I added caraway seed as well as the cloves, same amount. It was really good.
Wonderful! I love it!
Wonderful! I love it!
I have to make this a whole day in advance to enjoy, and use half the sugar. Tastes better than sauerkraut.
BOMB! love it! super easy too! my boyfriend loves it
Love this recipe, I omit the sugar and it’s still excellent. I appreciate how easy and delicious this recipe is!

I prepared this last night paired with grilled pork chops. I followed the recipe to the “T”. It was simple, fast and absolutely delicious with abundance of flavor. This will me become a new staple recipe.
My boyfriend ate three helpings! I love this recipe. I added an onion, used dark brown sugar instead of white sugar, and halved the salt, after reading other reviews.

Really good easy recipe and very tasty. I make it vegan by using Earth Balance butter substitute. Also, 5 cups of shredded cabbage for me only made a small amount. I'd shred a whole head of cabbage to make about 9 or 10 cups. 
i used the rest of the amounts called for but will double them next time.
Also, it seemed as if there was not enough liquid so I added about 1 T water here and there to make sure it didn't burn. 
My cooking time was just shy of 1.5 hours and it was perfect.
thank you!
Loved it! We cooked it in the crock pot on low for four hours. It gets better as it ages. Delicious on hot dogs!

This is a great recipe for German Red Cabbage. There are 2 important details that make it ABSOLUTELY fantastic. 1. add a little chopped bacon to the recipe and 2. Serve it after cooking/reheating it again, a second night. 
The bacon, (and serving it after it has been cooked twice), made this a recipe worthy of an authentic German restaurant!
So easy and delicious! I actually had an extra bowl of this instead of dessert. Will be making this often. Thank you so much for sharing this great recipe.

This dish turned out far more delicious than I imagined it would be even after reading the rave reviews. 
Now I have no red cabbage but have a large bag of store bought shredded cabbage (Cole slaw) and I'm going to use the same remaining ingredients a d monitor it for time and see what happens. Hey, desperate times call for desperate measures
We loved it
This was excellent
absolutely melt in your mouth delicious...I did add half an onion sliced...personal preference, love this dish
put diced onion and also a little bit of brown sugar along with regular sugar.
Delicious and easy
Easy and good. Use 2 tbsp brown sugar and 1/2 cup vinegar. Don’t worry that it starts looking dry. Push nearly done cabbage aside and brown kielbasa slices with a little stir fry sauce.

Giving this recipe 4 stars instead of 5, as I found the recipe almost too simple. I know it seems quite elementary, but there is no direction to check/stir the cabbage while simmering for 1 1/2 hours, which unfortunately resulted in a completely burnt cabbage bottom to my stainless steel pot. I recognize that stainless steel is more sensitive to heat than a non-stick or dutch oven, so I probably should have been more cautious - However, a heads up or extra step in the instructions would have been helpful. The cabbage that survived was quite tasty, and I am motivated to try this recipe again, but for those who may need the notice - Remember to stir here and there while your cabbage simmers!
Very good! Made this exactly as written minus 1/2 tsp salt. I will definitely use this recipe again.
I would have added a bit more vinegar but taste and texture were great.

I've made this many times, just as written and it always turns out great. It's hard not to eat a bit each time I stir it, but it's worth the wait! I didn't have an apple this time, so I used apple sauce and it came out just as good. You might cut down the sugar a bit if you prefer it not as sweet, but all in all, a great dish! Thank you!
Great. Delicious. I made it in the pressure cooker on high for 20 minutes. Next time I will pressure cook it for 15 minutes. Also I used margarine instead of butter so it is vegan.

I really like this recipe except for .......... It took much longer to cook than indicated by the recipe. Maybe it was because the cabbage that I used had rather large ribs? Anyway, it was quite odorous as others have mentioned. The cabbage was still "chewy" after 2 hours, but after 4 hours of simmering the cabbage was nice and soft and just plain delicious.
So easy to make and delicious!

Yum! I diced the apples rather than sliced them—don't do that (they got mushy and kinda gross). Next time I'll either make sure to slice them or I'll use applesauce like another reviewer suggested. I will definitely make this again!
Almost identical to my Gramma's. Hers was by guess and by gosh.
Way too salty!! I would definitely make it again but reduce the salt to 1 teaspoon.
This is my go-to recipe for Rotkohl. Tastes exactly like the best red cabbage I've eaten in Germany.
Made exactly as stated in recipe. AMAZING!!! Can't stop eating it ....
It is really easy to make and very good. Will definitely be making it again. Plus, it looks pretty on a plate.
Delicious! I made it exactly as written. My dad who loves german cuisine loved it!

Dang Grandma Jeanette! (Sara) you have GOT SOME GAME GIRL!!!! 

Every once in a while I volunteer cook the Senior Lunch at my local community centre - and today (Oct 30th) the theme was "Oktoberfest" - so I made a German-inspired lunch... fried potato pancake with bratwurst on top with gravy, pretzel and GRANDMA JEANETTE'S RED CABBAGE.

WOW. Everyone was raving about the red cabbage! Never mind the potatoes, never mind the Bratwurst... we had more compliments and recipe requests for the red cabbage.

I have eaten a fair share of red cabbage in my life and I never imagined it could be this good! Thank you for making me a star cook!
Made it exactly the same. Tasted just like my Grandmas and no one has her recipe so I will stick to using this one. Thank you for the recipe!
I added a pinch of cinnamon. As a diabetic, I watch my sugar intake so I substituted the sugar with a sugar alternative and it came out just as yummy!
I didn't change a thing. Delicious.
I did use applesauce like another person commented on. It was the best we ever had.
This is a very good recipe. I sauteed onions before adding the other ingredients. Easy and Yummy!!!
I added onions and no sugar. Better than any I have had a restaurants. Love it and sooo easy.
I add chopped cooked bacon because, well who doesn’t LOVE bacon!
Excellent made just like the recipe.
I made it close to the way the recipe calls except I did put in handful of chopped onion I had left over. It was very good not too sweet - just right.

item.name: Grandma Jeanette's Amazing German Red Cabbage
